ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think the course could be a lot more valuable to students with a few tweaks.

Professor Benoit clearly couldn't care less about teaching. He puts in as little effort as possible, and just wants to go on the field trip with the students he wants (which are usually pretty girls, the guy is a real creeper). Despite having an active interest in the topic of the course, I learned next to nothing and was disappointed in almost all aspects of the course. Even the field trip wasn't an academic experience, as it was mainly just drinking on the beach and touring around. That being said, the trip was a great time, and the reason I took the course. As you can tell from previous evaluations, you certainly don't take this class to learn anything.

Course covered broad spectrum of issues relevant to those interested in coastal development issues. Given the interests of the type of person who likely will sign up for this class, a stronger focus on management and policy aspects may be good in the future.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trip was great, though a little chaotic.
The trip and the outside speakers who came to lecture in class were the best part of the class. Loved that we got to meet the man who developed the eco-standards for St. John.
The field trip was an awesome time, and gives you an opportunity to do other things that interest you in the Caribbean during Spring Break.

The field trip was invaluable to the course. I learned more in a week in St. Thomas than I did during class the rest of the semester. I was able to bounce ideas off Gabe and Mary Beth about my project while we were there, and was able to use resources on the island that were unavailable here on campus.
Field trip and final paper were great applications

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The classes where students present the information in the readings should be more of a discussion than "lecture style". Everyone could sit around the table to discuss the material as an engaged group rather than having to sit through a power point presentations where more than half the class is not really paying attention and doing work for other classes on computers. The "presenter" could be the one responsible for answering questions and leading the discussion and have a typed up outline of the points for discussion. Trip: Give students the time to have interviews needed for their research. Make use of more local expertise as well. There are many on the island.

Just about everything. See my answer to number 13. Really, the course just needs a new professor. Gabe Benoit is hands down the worst teacher at the school, and that's not just coming from me, but literally dozens of other students that I've talked to about it.

The course should be more discussion based rather than presentation-style. I would have liked to see more teaching done by the professors rather than the students. The instructors could have been much better organized--many of the meetings on the island fell through while we were there, and classes were cancelled twice ten minutes before class was supposed to meet. Very annoying for those of us who could have planned our days better.
Student-led discussions were hard to actually generate discussion.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: See above. Would have like to see more lectures from Marybeth Decker as well. (one was not enough)

The course is just really poorly taught, with no one really interested in the lectures, which are just given by students on a range of topics that aren't really tied together well or flowing. The worst are when Professor Benoit himself gives the lectures, then they're real sleepers.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is a huge component of my overall program so I was very happy to be part of this class.

Most students in the course are focused on Marine/Coastal issues, as am I. That being said, we learned next to nothing. It did help that we got to go down to the Caribbean though. Other than that, the course work here at Yale was useless.

I took this class for fun, but ended up learning a lot about how land development and waste generation is dealt with in isolated islands in the Caribbean and how these US territories are not necessarily held under as strict guidelines as the mainland.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The material is a major component of my studies at F&ES. I took this class to learn more about reef to ridge management as well as the effects of both on the other. I wanted to learn more about how tropical coastal ecosystems are effected by development and the possible measures to mitigate this (political, social and environmental).
I knew it would be a bad course, but I wanted to go on the field trip, and it was an awesome time.
I am interested in marine issues, and figured this would be an opportunity to explore those interests.
Interested in coastal issues and local community management

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not entirely. Wanted to engage more with the people on the ground who are involved in the management of these coastal ecosystems. Wanted to learn or at least be exposed to options for holistic management.
I had heard from previous students that it was a terrible course, so I didn't expect much, but even so, it was worse than I thought it could have been.
Anticipated a greater focus on policy but this may have just been misinformation on my part and not a fault of the course

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The only group work was at the house in St. Thomas - That was great!

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Contact the people you want to interview before heading to St. Thomas. Start writing your paper the 3rd week of school :D

Only take it if you understand you're doing it for the trip to the Caribbean during Spring Break. And then if you do take it, make sure to get some extra funding and go to the Caribbean for at least the whole two weeks. Also, if you are a girl, stay as far away from Gabe Benoit as possible. There were many uncomfortable and unacceptable moments from him on the trip, so just be aware of that.

This course is what you make of it. The professors will put in the extra effort if you ask for their help, but will do minimal work otherwise. Come in with an idea you might be interested in, as you will be conducting research for your final project almost entirely on your own.
